# 5. ASYMPTOTIC RATIONAL POWERS OVER ALGEBRAICALLY CLOSED FIELDS 

This section is devoted to the proof of Theorem 5.2 (or Theorem C). We will use the following notation throughout.

Setup 5.1. Let $\mathbb{k}$ be an algebraically closed field. Let $R$ and $S$ be $\mathbb{k}$-algebras, and $I \subset R$ and $J \subset S$ nonzero ideals. We denote by $I T+J T$ the $T$-ideal $I T+J T$, where $T:=R \otimes_{\mathbb{k}} S$.

The following is a main theorem of this section. We note that, by Remark 2.18, the sum on the left hand side is finite.

Theorem 5.2. Adopt Setup 5.1 with $R$ and $S$ being finitely generated $\mathbb{k}$-algebras and normal domains. There exists $w_{0} \in \mathbb{Q}_{>0}$ such that if $w_{0} \leqslant \tau \leqslant w-w_{0}, \tau \in \mathbb{Q}$ then

$$
\sum_{\substack{0 \leq \alpha \leq w_{1} \\ \alpha \in \mathbb{Q}}} \overline{I^{\alpha} J^{\alpha-\alpha}} T \subseteq \overline{(I T+J T)^{w}} \subseteq \overline{I^{\tau}} T+\overline{J^{w-\tau}} T
$$

Remark 5.3. We note that by [49, proof of Lemma 1.2] we have

$$
\sum_{\substack{0 \leq \tau \leq w_{1} \\ \tau \in \mathbb{Q}}} \overline{I^{\tau} J^{\alpha-\tau}} T=\bigcap_{\substack{0 \leq \tau \leq w_{1} \\ \tau \in \mathbb{Q}}}\left(\overline{I^{\tau}} T+\overline{J^{w-\tau}} T\right)
$$

therefore Theorem 5.2 can be seen as a weaker version of the summation formula in Conjecture 1.1.
Before presenting the proof of the theorem, we need some preparatory results. We start with the following statement, which is a generalization of [37, Theorem 2.3] that is suitable for our purposes. First, we need the following definitions.

Definition 5.4 ( [37]). Let $R$ be a regular domain and $\mathbf{x}=x_{1}, \ldots, x_{d}$ a permutable regular sequence of $R$. We say $\mathbf{x}$ is a generalized regular system of parameters (grsop), if for every subset

$\mathbf{x}^{\prime}=x_{i_{1}}, \ldots, x_{i_{r}}$ of $\mathbf{x}$ the ring $R /\left(\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right)$ is also a regular domain. Let $\mathbf{x}$ be an grsop and let $I$ be an $R$-ideal generated by monomials in $\mathbf{x}$, i.e., $I=\left(\mathbf{x}^{\mathbf{a}_{1}}, \ldots, \mathbf{x}^{\mathbf{a}_{r}}\right)$, where if $\mathbf{a}=\left(a_{1}, \ldots, a_{d}\right) \in \mathbb{Z}_{\geqslant 0}^{d}$ then $\mathbf{x}^{\mathbf{a}}:=x_{1}^{a_{1}} \cdots x_{d}^{a_{d}}$. The Newton polyhedron of $I$ is defined as

$$
\operatorname{NP}(I):=\operatorname{conv}\left(\mathbf{a}_{1}, \ldots, \mathbf{a}_{s}\right)+\mathbb{R}_{\geqslant 0}^{d} \subseteq \mathbb{R}^{d}
$$

Theorem 5.5. Let $R, \mathbf{x}$, and I be as in Definition 5.4. For every $w \in \mathbb{Q}_{\geqslant 0}$ the ideal $\overline{I^{w}}$ is generated by the monomials $\mathbf{x}^{\mathbf{e}}$ with $\mathbf{e} \in w \mathrm{NP}(I)$.

Proof. We only include relevant details of how a modification of the proof of [37, Theorem 2.3] leads to our statement. We refer the reader to the proof of [37, Theorem 2.3] for any undefined notation, which we will follow closely.

Let $\mathbf{e} \in w \mathrm{NP}(I)$ and $c_{1}, \ldots, c_{s} \in \mathbb{Q}_{\geqslant 0}$ be such that $\sum_{i} c_{i}=w$ and $\mathbf{e} \geqslant \sum_{i} c_{i} \mathbf{a}_{i}$ componentwise. Write $c_{i}=\frac{m_{i}}{n}$ and $w=\frac{p}{q}$ where $m_{i}, p \in \mathbb{Z}_{\geqslant 0}$ and $n, q \in \mathbb{Z}_{>0}$. Therefore, $q n \mathbf{e} \geqslant \sum_{i} q m_{i} \mathbf{a}_{i}$. It follows that

$$
\left(\mathbf{x}^{q \mathbf{e}}\right)^{n} \in I^{\sum_{i} q m_{i}}=\left(I^{p}\right)^{n}
$$

and then $\left(\mathbf{x}^{\mathbf{e}}\right)^{q} \in \overline{I^{p}}$, i.e., $\mathbf{x}^{\mathbf{e}} \in \overline{I^{w}}$.
We proceed with the reverse inclusion. Let $H$ be a non-coordinate supporting hyperplane of $\mathrm{NP}(I)$ defined by $\langle\mathbf{h}, \mathbf{X}\rangle=h$ where $\mathbf{h}=\left(h_{1}, \ldots, h_{d}\right) \in \mathbb{Z}_{\geqslant 0}^{d}, h \in \mathbb{Z}_{>0}$, and $\mathbf{X}=\left(X_{1}, \ldots, X_{d}\right)$. Let $I_{H}$ be the ideal generated by the monomials $\mathbf{x}^{\mathbf{e}}$ with $\langle\mathbf{h}, \mathbf{e}\rangle \geqslant h$. It suffices to show that the conclusion of the theorem holds for $I_{H}$. Let $\mathfrak{p}=\left(Y_{1}, \ldots, Y_{t}\right) R^{\prime}$. By Proposition 2.9 and [38, Corollary 5.4.2], the rational powers of $\mathfrak{p}^{h} R_{\mathfrak{q}}^{\prime}$ have no embedded primes for every prime ideal $\mathfrak{p} \subseteq \mathfrak{q}$. Thus, it suffices to show that $\overline{\left(\mathfrak{p}^{h} R_{\mathfrak{p}}^{\prime}\right)^{\bar{w}}}=\mathfrak{p}^{\lceil w h\rceil} R_{\mathfrak{p}}^{\prime}$, which follows from $\mathfrak{p} R_{\mathfrak{p}}^{\prime}$ being a prime ideal generated by a regular sequence, as in this case the powers $\mathfrak{p}^{n} R_{\mathfrak{p}}^{\prime}$ are integrally closed and $\operatorname{gr}_{R_{\mathfrak{p}}^{\prime}}\left(\mathfrak{p} R_{\mathfrak{p}}^{\prime}\right):=\oplus_{n \in \mathbb{Z}_{\geqslant 0}} \mathfrak{p}^{n} R_{\mathfrak{p}}^{\prime} / \mathfrak{p}^{n+1} R_{\mathfrak{p}}^{\prime}$ is a domain.

Corollary 5.6. Let $\mathbb{k}$ be an algebraically closed field. Let $\left(V_{1}, \eta_{1}\right)$ and $\left(V_{2}, \eta_{2}\right)$ be two divisorial valuation rings containing $\mathbb{k}$ and such that $V:=V_{1} \otimes_{\mathbb{k}} V_{2}$ is Noetherian. Let $I=\left(\eta_{1}^{n_{1}}\right)$ and $J=\left(\eta_{2}^{n_{2}}\right)$ be ideals of $V_{1}$ and $V_{2}$, respectively. For every $\tau, w \in \mathbb{Q}_{\geqslant 0}$ with $\tau \leqslant w$, we have the following inclusion of $V$-ideals

$$
\overline{(I T+J T)^{w}} \subseteq \overline{I^{\tau}} T+\overline{J^{w-\tau}} T
$$

Proof. By [57, Theorem 6(e)] and [5, Chapter V, §17.2, Corollary], $V$ is a regular domain and $\eta_{1}, \eta_{2}$ is a grsop of $V$ (see Definition 5.4). Thus by Theorem 5.5 the ideal $\overline{(I T+J T)^{w}}$ is generated by the monomials $\eta_{1}^{e_{1}} \eta_{2}^{e_{2}}$ with $n_{2} e_{1}+n_{1} e_{2} \geqslant w n_{1} n_{2}$. Therefore, for any such $\eta_{1}^{e_{1}} \eta_{2}^{e_{2}}$ we must have $e_{1} \geqslant \tau n_{1}$ or $e_{2} \geqslant(w-\tau) n_{2}$. The result follows as $\overline{I^{\tau}}$ is generated by $\eta_{1}^{\left\lceil\tau n_{1}\right\rceil}$ and $\overline{J^{w-\tau}}$ by $\eta_{2}^{\left\lfloor(w-\tau) n_{2}\right\rceil}$.

The following lemma offers a vanishing result for rational powers of exceptional divisors of normalized blowups that can be of independent utility and interest.

Lemma 5.7. Adopt Setup 2.15. Let $v: X^{+} \longrightarrow X$ be the normalization of the blowup of $X$ along $\mathscr{I}$, and let $E$ be its exceptional divisor, i.e., $\mathscr{I} \cdot \mathscr{O}_{X^{+}}=\mathscr{O}_{X^{+}}(-E)$. Then there exists a positive integer $n$ such that if $\beta \in \mathbb{Q}$ and $\beta \geqslant n$ we have $R^{1} v_{*}\left(\mathscr{O}_{X^{+}}(-\lceil\beta E\rceil)\right)=0$.

Proof. Set $\mathcal{T}:=\mathscr{O}_{X^{+}}(-E)$. By Lemma 2.19 we have $\overline{\mathcal{T}^{\beta}}=\mathscr{O}_{X^{+}}(-\lceil\beta E\rceil)$ for every $\beta \in \mathbb{Q}_{\geqslant 0}$. Notice that there exists $m \in \mathbb{Z}_{>0}$ such that for every $\beta \geqslant m$ we have $\left(\overline{\mathcal{T}^{+}}\right)^{\beta+m}=\left(\overline{\mathcal{T}^{+}}\right)^{\beta}\left(\overline{\mathcal{T}^{+}}\right)^{m}$. Indeed, for any finite affine cover $\left\{U_{\lambda}\right\}_{\lambda \in \Lambda}$ of $X^{+}$, this holds locally on each $U_{\lambda}$ by Proposition 2.13(3), producing finitely many $m_{\lambda}$. So, we take can take $m:=\operatorname{lcm}\left(m_{\lambda} \mid \lambda \in \Lambda\right)$. Therefore for every $\beta \geqslant m$ we have

$$
\overline{\left(\mathcal{T}^{+}\right)^{\beta}}=\overline{\left(\mathcal{T}^{+}\right)^{\beta-m \left\lfloor\frac{\beta}{m}\right\rfloor+m}}\left(\overline{\left(\mathcal{T}^{+}\right)^{m}}\right)^{\left\lfloor\frac{\beta}{m}\right\rfloor-1} \cong \overline{\left(\mathcal{T}^{+}\right)^{\beta-m\lfloor\beta / m\rfloor+m}} \otimes \mathscr{O}_{X^{+}}(-E)^{\otimes m\lfloor\beta / m\rfloor-m}
$$

where the last isomorphism holds by flatness. Since $m \leqslant \beta-m\lfloor\beta / m\rfloor+m \leqslant 2 m$, by Remark 2.18 there are finitely many distinct ideal sheaves of the form $\overline{\left(\mathcal{T}^{+}\right)^{\beta-m\lfloor\beta / m\rfloor+m}}$. Since $\mathscr{O}_{X^{+}}(-E)$ is ample, by Serre's vanishing theorem [33, Proposition III.5.3] there exists $n \in \mathbb{Z}_{>0}$ such that for every $\beta \geqslant n$

$$
R^{1} v_{*}\left(\overline{\left(\mathcal{T}^{+}\right)^{\beta-m\lfloor\beta / m\rfloor+m}} \otimes \mathscr{O}_{X^{+}}(-E)^{\otimes m\lfloor\beta / m\rfloor-m}\right)=0
$$

The result now follows by combining (4) and (5).

We are now ready to prove the main theorem of this section.

Proof of Theorem 5.2. Fix $\alpha, w \in \mathbb{Q}_{\geqslant 0}$ with $0 \leqslant \alpha \leqslant w$. By Proposition 2.14 we have

$$
\overline{I^{\alpha} J^{w-\alpha}} T=\overline{(I T)^{\alpha}(J T)^{w-\alpha}} \subseteq \overline{(I T+J T)^{w}}
$$

proving the first inclusion. We proceed with the second inclusion to show that there exists $w_{0} \in \mathbb{Q}_{>0}$ such that

$$
\overline{(I T+J T)^{w}} \subseteq \overline{I^{x}} T+\overline{J^{w-\tau}} T
$$

for all $w_{0} \leqslant \tau \leqslant w-w_{0}, \tau \in \mathbb{Q}$. Let $X_{1}=\operatorname{Spec}(R)$ and $X_{2}=\operatorname{Spec}(S)$ so that $X_{1} \times X_{2}=\operatorname{Spec}(T)$. Let $\mathscr{I}=\bar{I} \subseteq O_{X_{1}}$ and $\mathscr{T}=\bar{J} \subseteq O_{X_{2}}$ be the sheaves associated to $I$ and $J$, respectively. Let $v_{1}: X_{1}^{+} \longrightarrow X_{1}$ and $v_{2}: X_{2}^{+} \longrightarrow X_{2}$ be the normalization of the blowups of $X_{1}$ and $X_{2}$ along $\mathscr{I}$ and $\mathscr{T}$, respectively, so that $\mathscr{I}^{+}:=\mathscr{I} \cdot \mathscr{O}_{X_{1}^{+}}=: \mathscr{O}_{X_{1}^{+}}\left(-E_{1}\right)$ and $\mathscr{T}^{+}:=\mathscr{T} \cdot \mathscr{O}_{X_{2}^{+}}=: \mathscr{O}_{X_{2}^{+}}\left(-E_{2}\right)$. Moreover, consider $Y:=X_{1} \times X_{2}, Y^{+}:=X_{1}^{+} \times X_{2}^{+}$, the canonical projections

$$
p_{1}: Y \longrightarrow X_{1}, \quad p_{2}: Y \longrightarrow X_{2}, \quad q_{1}: Y^{+} \longrightarrow X_{1}^{+}, \quad q_{2}: Y^{+} \longrightarrow X_{2}^{+}
$$

and $f:=v_{1} \times v_{2}: Y^{+} \longrightarrow Y$. These maps are represented in the following diagram.
![img-6.jpeg](img-6.jpeg)

We note that it suffices to show that the following two claims are true. Here, for simplicity of notation, for an ideal sheaf $\mathscr{J} \subseteq O_{X_{i}^{+}}$, resp. $\mathscr{J} \subseteq O_{X_{i}}$, we write $q_{i}^{-1} \mathscr{J}$, resp. $p_{i}^{-1} \mathscr{J}$, for the ideal sheaf $q_{i}^{-1} \mathscr{J} \cdot \mathscr{O}_{Y^{+}}$, resp. $p_{i}^{-1} \mathscr{J} \cdot \mathscr{O}_{Y}$. We note that, since each $q_{i}, p_{i}$ is flat, the latter are isomorphic to $q_{i}^{*} \mathscr{J}$, resp. $p_{i}^{*} \mathscr{J}$.
Claim 1: For any rational number $0 \leqslant \tau \leqslant w$ we have

$$
\overline{\left(q_{1}^{-1} \mathscr{I}^{+}+q_{2}^{-1} \mathscr{T}^{+}\right)^{w}} \subseteq q_{1}^{-1} \overline{\left(\mathscr{I}^{+}\right)^{\tau}}+q_{2}^{-1} \overline{\left(\mathscr{T}^{+}\right)^{w-\tau}}
$$

Claim 2: There exists $w_{0} \in \mathbb{Q}_{>0}$ such that if $w_{0} \leqslant \tau \leqslant w-w_{0}, \tau \in \mathbb{Q}$ then

$$
f_{*}\left(q_{1}^{-1} \overline{\left(\mathscr{I}^{+}\right)^{\tau}}+q_{2}^{-1} \overline{\left(\mathscr{T}^{+}\right)^{w-\tau}}\right)=f_{*}\left(q_{1}^{-1} \overline{\left(\mathscr{I}^{+}\right)^{\tau}}\right)+f_{*}\left(q_{2}^{-1} \overline{\left(\mathscr{T}^{+}\right)^{w-\tau}}\right)
$$

Indeed, if both claims hold, since $q_{1}^{-1} \mathscr{I}^{+}+q_{2}^{-1} \mathscr{T}^{+}=f^{-1}\left(p_{1}^{-1} \mathscr{I}+p_{2}^{-1} \mathscr{T}\right) \cdot \mathscr{O}_{Y^{+}}$, then from Theorem 2.20 one obtains

$$
\begin{aligned}
\overline{\left(p_{1}^{-1} \mathscr{I}+p_{2}^{-1} \mathscr{T}\right)^{w}}=f_{*}\left(\overline{\left(q_{1}^{-1} \mathscr{I}^{+}+q_{2}^{-1} \mathscr{T}^{+}\right)^{w}}\right) & \subseteq f_{*}\left(q_{1}^{-1} \overline{\left(\mathscr{I}^{+}\right)^{\tau}}\right)+f_{*}\left(q_{2}^{-1} \overline{\left(\mathscr{T}^{+}\right)^{w-\tau}}\right) \\
& =p_{1}^{-1} \overline{\left(\mathscr{I}\right)^{\tau}}+p_{2}^{-1} \overline{\left(\mathscr{T}\right)^{w-\tau}}
\end{aligned}
$$

for $w_{0} \leqslant \tau \leqslant w-w_{0}, \tau \in \mathbb{Q}$. The last equality follows from Künneth formula (see [55, tag 0BEC, Lemma 33.29.1] and [34, Proposition III.8.5]) using Theorem 2.20 and the facts that $v_{1 *}\left(\mathscr{O}_{X_{1}^{+}}\right)=\mathscr{O}_{X_{1}}$ and $v_{2 *}\left(\mathscr{O}_{X_{2}^{+}}\right)=\mathscr{O}_{X_{2}}$ [34, proof of Corollary III.11.4]. Thus, (6) will follow by taking global sections, see Remark 2.17.

We proceed to prove Claim 1, for which we can restrict to a product of affine schemes $U_{1} \times U_{2} \subset$ $Y^{+}$, where $U_{1}=\operatorname{Spec}\left(A_{1}\right) \subset X_{1}^{+}, V=\operatorname{Spec}\left(A_{2}\right) \subset X_{2}^{+}$, and $A_{1}$ and $A_{2}$ are Noetherian normal domains. Therefore $\mathscr{I}^{+}$and $\mathscr{T}^{+}$can be identified with principal ideals $\left(a_{1}\right) \subseteq A_{1}$ and $\left(a_{2}\right) \subseteq A_{2}$, respectively, and $q_{1}^{-1} \mathscr{I}^{+}+q_{2}^{-1} \mathscr{T}^{+}$with $\left(a_{1}\right) A+\left(a_{2}\right) A$ where $A:=A_{1} \otimes_{k} A_{2}$. By Proposition 2.9 and [38, Corollary 5.4.2] the associated primes of the rational powers $\overline{\left(a_{1}\right)^{\tau}}$ and $\overline{\left(a_{2}\right)^{w-\tau}}$ all have codimension one. By [32, Corollary 2.8] the associated primes of $\left(a_{1}\right) A+\left(a_{2}\right) A$ are sums $\mathrm{p}_{1} A+\mathrm{p}_{2} A$ with $\mathrm{p}_{i}$ associated prime of $\left(a_{i}\right), i=1,2$. Moreover, rational powers localize by Proposition 2.4. Thus, to show $\overline{\left(\overline{\left(a_{1}\right) A+\left(a_{2}\right) A\right)^{w}} \subseteq \overline{\left(a_{1}\right)^{\tau}} A+\overline{\left(a_{2}\right)^{w-\tau}} A$, it suffices to do so in the localizations $\left(A_{1}\right)_{\mathrm{p}_{1}} \otimes_{k}\left(A_{2}\right)_{\mathrm{p}_{2}}$. But the latter follows from Corollary 5.6, finishing the proof of Claim 1.

We continue with the proof of Claim 2. Consider the exact sequence

$$
0 \longrightarrow q_{1}^{-1} \overline{\left(\mathscr{I}^{+}\right)^{\tau}} \cap q_{2}^{-1} \overline{\left(\mathscr{T}^{+}\right)^{w-\tau}} \longrightarrow q_{1}^{-1} \overline{\left(\mathscr{I}^{+}\right)^{\tau}} \oplus q_{2}^{-1} \overline{\left(\mathscr{T}^{+}\right)^{w-\tau}}
$$

$$
\longrightarrow q_{1}^{-1} \overline{(\mathscr{I}+)^{\tau}}+q_{2}^{-1} \overline{(\mathscr{T}+)^{w-\tau}} \longrightarrow 0
$$

Applying $f_{*}$, the claim reduces to showing

$$
R^{1} f_{*}\left(q_{1}^{-1} \overline{(\mathscr{I}+)^{\tau}} \cap q_{2}^{-1} \overline{(\mathscr{T}+)^{w-\tau}}\right)=R^{1} f_{*}\left(q_{1}^{-1} \overline{(\mathscr{I}+)^{\tau}} \otimes q_{2}^{-1} \overline{(\mathscr{T}+)^{w-\tau}}\right)=0
$$

By Künneth formula it suffices to show that there exists $w_{0} \in \mathbb{Q}_{>0}$ such that if $\beta \in \mathbb{Q}$ and $\beta \geqslant w_{0}$ then

$$
R^{1} v_{1 *}\left(\overline{(\mathscr{I}+)^{\beta}}\right)=0 \quad \text { and } \quad R^{1} v_{2 *}\left(\overline{(\mathscr{T}+)^{\beta}}\right)=0
$$

The latter vanishings hold by Lemma 5.7, concluding the proof of Claim 2. This finishes the proof of the theorem.

Remark 5.8. We note that if for certain ideals $I$ and $J$ the vanishings in (7) hold for every $\beta \geqslant 0$, then the proof of Theorem 5.2 shows that these ideals satisfy the conclusion of Conjecture 1.1.

By working locally in affine open subsets, Theorem 5.2 implies the following more general statement (cf. [49, Theorem 0.3]). As in the proof of Theorem 5.2, we denote by $p^{-1} \mathscr{J}$, resp. $q^{-1} \mathscr{J}$, the ideal sheaves $p^{-1} \mathscr{J} \cdot \mathscr{O}_{X \times Y}$, resp. $q^{-1} \mathscr{J} \cdot \mathscr{O}_{X \times Y}$.

Corollary 5.9. Let $X, Y$ be normal varieties over an algebraically closed field $\mathbb{k}$. Let $\mathscr{I} \subseteq$ $\mathscr{O}_{X}, \mathscr{T} \subseteq \mathscr{O}_{y}$ be nonzero ideal sheaves, and $p: X \times Y \longrightarrow X, q: X \times Y \longrightarrow Y$ the canonical projections. There exists $w_{0} \in \mathbb{Q}_{>0}$ such that if $w_{0} \leqslant \tau \leqslant w-w_{0}, \tau \in \mathbb{Q}$ then

$$
\sum_{\substack{0 \leqslant n \leqslant w \\ \alpha \in \mathbb{Q}}} p^{-1} \overline{\mathscr{I}^{\alpha}} q^{-1} \overline{\mathscr{T}^{w-\alpha}} \subseteq \overline{\left(p^{-1} \mathscr{I}+q^{-1} \mathscr{T}\right)^{w}} \subseteq p^{-1} \overline{(\mathscr{I})^{\tau}}+q^{-1} \overline{(\mathscr{T})^{w-\tau}}
$$

Similarly as in [49, Proposition 2.1], the formula in Theorem 5.2 can be used to approximate rational powers up to m -adic neighborhoods. This is also related to the main theorem in [23, 24].

Corollary 5.10. Adopt Setup 5.1 with $R$ a finitely generated $\mathbb{k}$-algebra and normal domain, and $S$ a polynomial ring with homogeneous maximal ideal $\mathfrak{m}$. For every $n \in \mathbb{Z}_{\geqslant 0}$, there exists $w_{0}=w_{0}(n) \in \mathbb{Q}_{>0}$ such that if $w, \ell \geqslant w_{0}$ then

$$
\overline{(I T+\mathfrak{m}^{n} T)^{w+\ell}} \subseteq \overline{I^{w}} T+\mathfrak{m}^{\lceil n \ell\rceil} T
$$

Moreover, for any nonzero ideal $J \subset S$ there exists a $w_{0} \in \mathbb{Q}_{>0}$ such that if $w, \ell \geqslant w_{0}$ then

$$
\overline{(I T+J T)^{w+\ell}} \subseteq \overline{I^{w}} T+J^{\lfloor\ell\rfloor-\operatorname{dim}(S)+1} T
$$

Proof. The first statement follows from Theorem 5.2 and since the powers of $m$ are integrally closed, then $\overline{\left(\mathfrak{m}^{n}\right)^{\ell}}=\mathfrak{m}^{\lceil n \ell\rceil}$. The second statement also follows from Theorem 5.2 and by the inclusions $\overline{J^{\ell}} \subseteq \overline{J^{\lfloor\ell\rfloor}} \subseteq J^{\lfloor\ell\rfloor-\operatorname{dim}(S)+1}$, which hold by the Briançon-Skoda Theorem [47] (see also [38, Corollary 13.3.4]).

abstract:
We provide explicit descriptions for the rational powers and Rees valuations
of several classes of ideals invariant under natural actions of tori and
products of general linear groups, in terms of polyhedra and lattice points.
This allows us to show that a version of Musta\c{t}\u{a}-Takagi's summation
formula for multiplier ideals also holds for the rational powers of these
ideals. Moreover, for arbitrary ideals in normal domains that are finitely
generated over algebraically closed fields, we prove a weaker version of this
formula that holds for sufficiently large rational numbers.
